keyTakeAways: A federal judge in Chicago issued a restraining order requiring federal agents to avoid using tear gas and less-lethal munitions during protests and to use body-worn cameras to document interactions.
The judge expressed serious concern that the Trump administration may not be following her orders, citing reports of tear gas deployment without warning and lack of body camera footage.

Federal officials, including CBP Deputy Incident Commander Kyle Harvick and ICE Deputy Field Office Director Shawn Byers, testified, but the judge insisted on accountability, noting that higher-ranking officials like Russell Hott and Gregory Bovino must eventually be deposed.
The judge emphasized transparency, stating that if officials cannot answer questions with knowledge or accountability, new individuals will be brought in until clear answers are given.
Protests continued at the Broadview ICE facility, with over 100 demonstrators gathering and 15 arrests made each day, showing public resistance to immigration enforcement actions.
The administration has denied reports of tear gas use without warning, claiming the media reports are selective and one-sided.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In a court hearing, U.S. District Judge Sara Ellis, an Obama appointee, expressed serious concern that federal agents under the Trump administration’s Operation Midway Blitz were not complying with her order to avoid using tear gas and less-lethal force during protests in Chicago. The judge demanded explanations for reports of tear gas deployment without warning and called for accountability, including from high-ranking officials like Russell Hott and Gregory Bovino. Federal officials, including CBP Deputy Incident Commander Kyle Harvick and ICE Deputy Field Office Director Shawn Byers, testified, asserting that all agents now wear body-worn cameras and that no disciplinary actions were taken for protest-related incidents. However, the judge remained skeptical and mandated that officials provide transparent, detailed responses or face replacement with more accountable personnel. Protests continued at the Broadview ICE facility, with over 100 demonstrators gathering and multiple arrests reported, underscoring ongoing public resistance to immigration enforcement actions.
title: Federal officials try to reassure judge they’re following her orders to tone down and record Chicagoland protest actions
